Innovation and the Web Erik Wilde (@dret): APIs for Innovation and Evolution

(8) Why the Web Won: Public APIs

  • Permissionless decentralized innovation
  • Global-scale access through well-defined interfaces
  • Implementation aspects are not part of the architecture


Innovation and the Web Erik Wilde (@dret): APIs for Innovation and Evolution

(9) Why Web Sites Win: Private APIs

  • Focus on change willingness and readiness
  • Experimentation and observation
  • Ruthless self-reinvention


APIs and Innovation

Outline (APIs and Innovation)

(11) Pre-API Innovation



APIs and Innovation Erik Wilde (@dret): APIs for Innovation and Evolution

(12) API Cargo Cult



APIs and Innovation Erik Wilde (@dret): APIs for Innovation and Evolution

(13) APIs are a Mechanism

  • Businesses need to become faster at changing
    • The need to change internally to adapt to changing markets and competition
    • The need to interface externally to provide and consume services
  • Value chains change faster than ever before
    • Improving flexibility and adaptability becomes essential strategy
  • There are two essential sides to getting APIs right
    1. All interactions with a service are done through its API
    2. Service implementations are managed as autonomous components


APIs and Innovation Erik Wilde (@dret): APIs for Innovation and Evolution

(14) APIs are Enablers

  • APIs are an essential component in IT-centric business
    • APIs are necessary: Enabling faster changes
    • APIs are not sufficient: Drive them from the why
  • The business goal is to become better at changing
    • Embrace diversity to minimize innovation barriers
    • Embrace failure as a way to understand the market
    • Move from prescribing to guiding
  • APIs allow to produce more digital products in less time


APIs and Innovation Erik Wilde (@dret): APIs for Innovation and Evolution

(15) APIs and Evolution

  • Stop building systems, start cultivating ecosystems
    • Systems are integrated solutions to solve specific problems
    • Ecosystems host components that can evolve to respond to changes


APIs and Innovation Erik Wilde (@dret): APIs for Innovation and Evolution

(16) The Big Picture



Good API Practice: Designing for Change

Outline (Good API Practice: Designing for Change)

  1. Introduction [4]
  2. Innovation and the Web [2]
  3. APIs and Innovation [6]
  4. Good API Practice: Designing for Change [4]
  5. Conclusions [2]
Good API Practice: Designing for Change Erik Wilde (@dret): APIs for Innovation and Evolution

(18) Plan for Evolution

  • Planning for evolution means to reduce pain in the future
    • No immediate benefits other than doing the right thing
    • Modest effort when part of the API design process and culture
  • Extensibility should be part of the API design culture
    • Each API must have and document a plan for API evolution
    • The simplest possible plan may be to never change the API


Good API Practice: Designing for Change Erik Wilde (@dret): APIs for Innovation and Evolution

(19) Meaningful Core Semantics

  • The core of the API allows clients to have meaningful interactions
    • The starting point of an API should be meaningful and complete
  • The core of the API is robust over time
    • Anything that is added to the core does not change the core semantics
  • Anything that is not part of the core can be safely ignored
    • mustIgnore semantics allow safe interactions beyond closely coordinated groups


Good API Practice: Designing for Change Erik Wilde (@dret): APIs for Innovation and Evolution

(20) Well-Defined Extension Points

  • APIs should be clear about where extensions are allowed
    • API metamodels often decide where (potential) extension points are
    • API schemas/definitions should further narrow down where extensions are allowed
  • API tests can make sure that the extension points are properly implemented
    • Extensions in allowed places are ignored and tests should succeed
    • Extensions in other places should raise errors about malformed content


Good API Practice: Designing for Change Erik Wilde (@dret): APIs for Innovation and Evolution

(21) Well-Defined Processing Model

  • Extensions are well-defined and their handling is well-defined as well
    • Extension points make it clear where to expect extensions
    • Processing models make it clear what to do with extensions
  • mustIgnore is a popular and good choice for extension processing
    • Some formats allow extensions to declare their processing model (such as mustUnderstand)
    • HTML has a rule of ignoring unknown elements but processing their content


Conclusions

Outline (Conclusions)

  1. Introduction [4]
  2. Innovation and the Web [2]
  3. APIs and Innovation [6]
  4. Good API Practice: Designing for Change [4]
  5. Conclusions [2]
Conclusions Erik Wilde (@dret): APIs for Innovation and Evolution

(23) APIs and Innovation

  • Innovation only works bottom-up
  • Loosely coupled ecosystems allow change and evolution
  • APIs are an essential component of IT ecosystems
  • APIs are the connective tissue for evolving ecosystems
    • New ideas can be quickly developed, deployed, and tested
    • Successful ideas can be easily scaled and safely evolved
    • Unsuccessful ideas can be safely phased out as required


Conclusions Erik Wilde (@dret): APIs for Innovation and Evolution
